ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: How to analyze primary and secondary sources, criticize where and how we get information, general historical knowledge of the way colonialism, capitalism, and climate science all intersect from a wide array of time periods

I have learned to read sources with a critical eye, to examine a primary source thoroughly, and to connect three topics I never thought I would! This is an amazing course, and I would totally recommend!
Critical thinking skills, especially in regards to epistemology, understanding the way knowledge came about in this particular field.

I learned more about how to look at a source for more than just its face value and how choosing certain sources can exacerbate a problem. Furthermore, I did not know a lot about climate science before this class and now I feel like I have left with a better understanding. It was very interesting to see how climate science connects with colonialism and economics.

We studied and analyzed knowledge production and how it is impacted by larger systems of racial capitalism, white supremacy, and colonialism. We specifically looked at the production of climate science and research on climate change.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
could be improved through a few more diverse readings/authors
also if the conversation was not all the time focused on the specific readings but if we organized discussions sometimes based on theme in broader contexts
strength - the essays were fun to write, i liked doing presentations, and small group discussions
Strengths: great instructor, the syllabus and readings are really engaging, and the assignments (weekly brief reading response, paper, and final project/paper) were all really well constructed

Strengths: I thoroughly enjoyed our class discussions. Oliver is great at facilitating the seminar discussions. Every class, he was prepared with great guiding questions at the same time, he left room for students to drive the conversation. His feedback on the weekly reading responses was always detailed. The material was very engaging, and I felt like I was learning something new in every seminar. 

Weaknesses: I think there could have been more guidance for what was expected from the presentation assignment but I also appreciate that it was fairly open-ended because every student approached it in different ways.

Great syllabus and discussion. I really like the weekly presentations idea that introduces the class to the readings and where they can be expanded upon. I really liked the group work that we did, beginning our reading evaluations in small groups and expanding the discussion from there. I think the class could benefit from more of that because it makes readings, particularly the longer ones, much more digestable and less intimidating from the beginning. I think sometimes our discussions were a bit weak and could've gone deeper so maybe some improvement in that regard.
The presentations every week helped with my understanding of the readings and the trip to another library was incredible. A weakness is I wish we had more group talks.

Appreciated the flexibility of the final paper! We had the option of doing a standard research paper, a creative project (ex. podcast, advocacy action plan, art exhibition, video performance, etc.) , or syllabus design (ie. reflection and expansion on the syllabus). I also appreciated our "midterm" (the primary source analysis), especially because a lot of the class was on knowledge production which informed how I understood the form/content of the archive I chose .

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes absolutely! I learned a lot in this class and the Oliver is a great instructor. The discussions were really engaging and I really loved the readings (which is not something I say lightly). The material is really important and I ended up leaving the class generally feeling like it reshaped the way I think about certain subjects.
Yes! It is a great way to connect these three topics that are of ultimate importance and urgency. It will make you view the world with a new lense.
Absolutely, I don't think I've taken a class at Yale that has shaped my perspective on a topic as much as this class.

Definitely. Absolutely fascinating content about three topics that seem unrelated. The seemingly unrelated nature of the topics in the title are what makes this course so valuable. You learn fascinating connections between fascinating topics. It is a very chill environment, you discuss as you see fit.
Yes, it was a very unique course, one that I have never seen before. Also, Oliver is great and really cares about your learning.

Yes! We studied and analyzed knowledge production and how it is impacted by larger systems of racial capitalism, white supremacy, and colonialism. We specifically looked at the production of climate science and research on climate change. Appreciated the flexibility of the final paper! We had the option of doing a standard research paper, a creative project (ex. podcast, advocacy action plan, art exhibition, video performance, etc.) , or syllabus design (ie. reflection and expansion on the syllabus). I also appreciated our "midterm" (the primary source analysis), especially because a lot of the class was on knowledge production which informed how I understood the form/content of the archive I chose. We also had a very understanding instructor who always tried to make his class accessible for all students. I really appreciated the written feedback I received. Oliver was very warm to everyone and very understanding that we were all coming in with different fields/levels of knowledge around colonial violence and climate change.
